text: I don't like echo chambers and I am totally against blocking or deleting comments just because they disagree with me or critize me. I don't have to reply and engage if I don't want to but why cancel or block anyone? If what they are saying is stupid, rude or downright wrong than why should I stop them from pubicly making a fool of themselves? And if critique triggers me that is usually a good indication that there is an ounce of truth in what was being said. People just can't deal with opposing opinions or critique anymore. Discussing something without people wanting to put a gag on each other has become impossible. It's sad. Maybe we should all just stay at home and ban all media so we never have to face people who simply disagree with us or who are just plain idiots. For those of us who can't deal with everyone's human right to have an opinion and voice it, no matter how unqualified it might be, a content creating social media presence might not be the most self-loving thing to do.

author: @NickNimmin

text:
What has probably happened is one of the following:
1) the channel has set their comments to hold for review anything that might contain specific words, and they have yet to approve the comments that got filtered. This can also happen to any comment with a link in it.
2) the channel saw the comments and removed them manually.

It is unlikely YouTube/Google themselves moderated them. If you feel a piece of content breaks a community guideline or presents dangerous information, you can report it to YouTube using the Report option under every video (often in the dot menus).

author: @NickNimmin

text: ¬†@NickNimmin¬† I do agree, but on the other hand this content is public, and if the channel is trying to promote misinformation this ability makes it easier for misinformation to be believed by those who read a slanted version of comments that the misinformation promoter wants people to see. Now of course I don't think this applies to the vast majority of channel owners. I do think platforms should do some random sweeps, and disable this ability for channel owners if they misuse it - maybe after a certain amount of warnings. Or have a trusted commenter policy, where certain people cannot be muted, based on their past behaviour. There can be ethical considerations of allowing someone to comment and correct the record, and not notifying that user that their perfectly valid and polite comment has been muted seems wrong. But of course I agree there is no need to notifying someone who is spamming or is being plain rude, I can see the proportionality in that. I appreciate that the admin overhead makes this policy difficult, and  probably not practical. But I do think it is really important that comments that challenge misinformation, lies, or simply provides context in a polite way should not be censored simply because the channel owner does not wish his audience to be aware. Perhaps an impossible balance to achieve, but I think there are ways we can minimise the issue. Sorry I wrote an essay.

text: Are your videos so perfect they're immune to criticism? Shadow-banning comment authors because they're "negative" is terrible advice. Labeling anyone who isn't full of praise as a "hater" who needs "dealing with" is a sore loser ideology. Disallowing anything other than praise and positivity is not good for anyone. There's a huge problem on youtube with artificial positivity, or fake and dishonest comments designed to promote and cross promote  rather than offer genuine feedback. text: I think either you have misunderstood or I have not effectively communicated in this video what I'm actually talking about when referring to "negative" comments. We're talking trolls, hateful comments, etc. There is a real culture in some circles of going after creators because they disagree, but instead of being civil, they come at creators with hate, threats and abuse. No one should have to put up with that.
author: @NickNimmin

text:
¬†@NickNimmin¬† The tools given to content creators to shadow-ban commenters are abused. That's just a fact. Nobody condones hate or abuse, but the problem is creators will often classify ALL criticism, or contested points, or expressive comments as "hate". 

Your assertion that people don't know they've been shadow-banned is false. Not getting any replies is a clear indicator. Easily confirmed by logging out and checking the comments.  This will cause resentment and possibly further unwanted comments by those same people under different accounts. 

"Going after creators".... via comments? Give me a break. Most people don't even read comments. Popular videos have so many comments it's impossible to see them all. You are advocating for gaffer taping the mouths of anyone who says something you don't like. The comments section doesn't actually "belong" to the content creator anyway. The idea you can dictate what words others can express is revolting. For example if the video is anti-abortion, you'll see comments disappearing that advocate for abortion rights. Same for many political topics. The shadow banning tools you describe as "awesome" are NOT awesome.

text: I feel like I can't post a comment without being spammed with negative replies about me and nothing positive or neutral. For example, when I made a comment about my autism on a video about disabilities, I received many replies. All of them told me to stop seeking attention. When I said a video was educational, I was told I was ignorant, watched too much Rick & Morty (I have never watched Rick & Morty before), and could not solve 2 + 2. In one video that compared the 1999 SpongeBob intro to the 2016 SpongeBob intro, I stated my honest opinion on which intro I preferred. However, I was called the r-word, told I sucked for not perceiving the intros the same way, and even received replies saying, "WTF". This is just 1% of the many times people have expressed negative attitudes towards me without anything positive or neutral. At this point, you could just tell me not to post the comment. However, I am opinionated, and I try to cope with that trait by stating my honest thoughts in the comment section. I try to be  intelligent and well-spoken, but it is extremely difficult for me since I have developmental disabilities.

text:
I was cussed out for no apparent reason this morning, and it was really shocking... I guess I've been sheltered, because I've never been on the receiving end of such bile. I googled what YouTube does if I report them, and was really disappointed. They won't do anything unless they are inciting violence. That leaves a lot of room for abuse!
I came to this video looking for some advice, and thank you for it. I'm not a "content creator" - I just want to be able to use this without the negativity. Since it seems YouTube doesn't care, I don't think I want to be using this website anymore.

text:
I can say this. Sometimes it can pay off in a positive way to react to their comments. I had someone just recently that said my intro was "too cringy" to watch the rest of the video and I gave them a simple response of "well my content isn't for everyone and I am okay with that." I don't think they expected a response, (or a response like that) and they weren't long backtracking and apologizing for what they said. 

I think sometimes it's not just a troll, but someone having a bad day and speaking to them can make them realize that their words are reaching another person and that can make them realize there is another person on the other side of that video wall and their words have meaning or consequence.

If they continue to talk crap after that initial response though... then yea... hide their crumpet from your channel.

text:
There was an expat out of Thailand who urged his followers to harass and troll over fifty other channels. During his three years on YouTube he stalked two other expats who had channels who never trolled him or met this guy. He drove hundreds of miles to Phuket Thailand to make videos for his channel stalking these two men. Later that night after stalking one of these men and his wife he later found himself in the hospital in the ER.
 Not long afterwards he focused on another YouTube channel a man dying of heart disease and he and his cult from his YouTube channel harassed him until he died a few days later. But that was not the end of the story. Not more than a day later he started attacking the man's wife and family from his channel. Now claiming the man faked his own death. This went on for over a month while still attacking multiple channels.
  Next it was another man with a YT channel dying of cancer. This mental case and his cult then went after him and up until just a month ago when his channel was taken down for a fifth time. For harassment, stalking, racist comments, etc, etc etc. Hundreds of people contacted YouTube either directly or reporting his channel online and YouTube allow this man for over a year at one period of time to attack others from his channel. While YouTube did nothing. This guy is now on a website off of YouTube making videos and continues harassing others. He now also has a friend from his YouTube channel doing his dirty work with the same followers harassing these other channels.
So my question is. Is there a direct e-mail address or toll free phone number to contact to YouTube? Reporting via YouTube a channel is a complete joke and a waste of time.
